title: 103_hr664
content: The "Domestic Timber Production and Manufacturing Incentives Act" is cited as an investment incentive for domestic timber production under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Domestic Timber Production and Manufacturing Incentives Act" allows taxpayers with qualified timber gain to deduct a percentage of the gain from gross income. Qualified timber gain is the lesser of net capital gain or net capital gain from qualified timber. Qualified timber is timber where processing will mostly occur in the United States. The "Domestic Timber Production and Manufacturing Incentives Act" allows taxpayers to deduct a qualified percentage of timber gain from gross income. The qualified percentage is determined by multiplying 2 percent by the number of years in the taxpayer's holding period for the timber. In the case of estates or trusts, the deduction excludes gains from sales or exchanges of capital assets includible by income beneficiaries. Coordination with existing limitations on capital gains rates is also addressed. The "Domestic Timber Production and Manufacturing Incentives Act" allows taxpayers to deduct qualified timber gain from gross income. The deduction is determined by multiplying 2 percent by the holding period for the timber. Coordination with existing limitations on capital gains rates is also addressed. The "Domestic Timber Production and Manufacturing Incentives Act" allows taxpayers to deduct qualified timber gain from gross income. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for part I of subchapter P of chapter 1 of the Code. The "Domestic Timber Production and Manufacturing Incentives Act" provides an investment incentive for domestic timber production. The amendments made by this section apply to sales or exchanges after the date of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, passive loss limitations are applied to timber activities. The "Domestic Timber Production and Manufacturing Incentives Act" provides an investment incentive for domestic timber production. Passive loss limitations are applied to timber activities, with new criteria for material participation in timber activities introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The taxpayer must directly retain and compensate individuals who are under their oversight, supervision, and control, or participate regularly, continuously, and substantially in the activity, without a minimum time requirement. The determination of whether a partner or S corporation shareholder is materially participating in a timber activity is based on their direct involvement or regular participation in the activity, without a specific time requirement. The amendment applies to partnerships or S corporations with combined participation in timber activities, effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
